title: Khavda Pottery
hero_image_alt: Red clay pots with black and white patterns
short_description: Distinctive red clay pottery from Kutch, Gujarat, painted with black and white geometric patterns using natural colors.
long_description:
Khavda pottery is an ancient art form from holding strong in the village of Khavda, North Kutch. The men bring the mud from the lakeside and shape it using a potter's wheel into various vessels. Once dried, the women of the house perform the painting.

Using a red slip (Gairu) as a base, they paint intricate designs in black and white. The black color consists of bamboo ash, while the white is made from white clay. The pottery is then fired, resulting in the signature terra-cotta color with distinct tribal motifs. It is deeply connected to the daily life of the region, used for storing water and cooking.
traditional_methods: Clay sourcing from Rann lake areas.
Hand painting by women using bamboo sticks.

major_centres.title: Khavda Village
major_centres.summary: The heart of this craft, located near the White Rann.

shipping_and_packaging_tips: Terracotta is porous and breakable. Hand carry if possible.
authenticity_tips: Look for the natural matte finish of the painting. It is not glazed.
local_economy_note: Vital income for manufacturing families in the arid Kutch region.
